newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: AUSTRALIA GOLD-Miners use low dollar to sell gold.
newsitem.headline: AUSTRALIA GOLD-Miners use low dollar to sell gold.

text.p: Reacting to a sharp fall in the value of the Australian dollar, some of Australia's gold mining companies took the opportunity to sell gold.
The activity, prompted by a surprise rise, albeit small, gain in the value of gold in Australian dollar terms, capped an otherwise routine week for gold, bullion dealers said.
The Australian dollar slumped more than 3/4 cent on Friday after the Reserve Bank of Australia cut official cash rates 0.5 percentage point to 5.5 percent.
"The fall in the Aussie dollar has led to a small amount of selling by some Australian gold producers," a dealer said.
When the Australian dollar declines against the benchmark U.S. currency it means Australian gold will fetch a higher return in Australian dollars.
The Perth Mint on Friday was quoting spot gold at A$446.32 an ounce based on an international price of US$343.13 an ounce.
On the previous day, an international price only nominally higher of US$343.43 compared with an A$443.54 an ounce quote by the mint.
That means that while gold in U.S. dollars actually fell 30 cents a pound, over the same one-day period Australian-dollar gold was up A$$2.78.

"Aussie dollar gold at the present price is really in familiar territory and not much help to producers looking to sell," the dealer said. "It certainly makes it more attractive on the day but I don't think it will attract a huge amount of selling."
However, it appears not many of the Australian producers took advantage of the potential gains, choosing instead to sit on their reserves, dealers said.
One reason offered by dealers is that even at the elevated level, the price is too low to attract much interest.
"There is a blue-sky perception that if you can hang on, the price will go up," another dealer said.
The average cost of producing gold in Australia is around A$370 an ounce, which doesn't leave much room for profits, taking into account associated outside costs.
Mine operating costs frequently hold more sway with investors than the gold price.
"A mining company may not be able to control the world price, but it is responsible for its own costs," said a mine analyst.
